===Etymology===
Originally a compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=つくよみ|月|tr1=tsuku|t1=the moon|読み|tr2=yomi|t2=reading|pos2=ancient meaning of “counting”}}, and referred to telling the [[phase]] (sense 4) of the moon.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

This spelling was later repurposed as [[熟字訓#Japanese|''jukujikun'']] for a compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=つくよみ|月|tr1=tsuku|t1=the moon|夜|tr2=yo|t2=night|神|tr3=mi|t3=god}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

The ''tsuku'' reading for {{m|ja|月}} is the ancient combining form.  ''Tsukuyomi'' is the older reading, and this appears to be less common.  {{m|ja|月}} is read as ''tsuki'' in modern {{etyl|ja|-}}, resulting in the more-common ''Tsukiyomi'' reading for this term.

====Derived terms====
* {{ja-l|月読男}}, {{ja-l|月夜見男|つくよみおとこ|Tsukuyomi otoko}}: [[personification]] of the moon, the moon man (not the "''[[man in the moon]]''")
* {{ja-l|月読尊}}, {{ja-l|月読命}}, {{ja-l|月夜見命|つくよみのみこと|Tsukuyomi no Mikoto}}: formal name for the Japanese god of the moon
* {{ja-l|月読宮}}, {{ja-l|月夜見宮}} ({{ja-l|つきよみのみや}}, {{ja-l|||Tsukiyomi no Miya}}; {{ja-l|つくよみのみや}}, {{ja-l|||Tsukuyomi no Miya}}): a shrine to Tsukuyomi in the Miyajiri area of [[w:Ise, Mie|Ise]], [[w:Mie Prefecture|Mie Prefecture]]
